text: Thank you to Rep Gonzalez for introducing legislation requiring @DHHS to study transmissibiity of COVID–19 from child to child, child to adult, adult to child. We need more information on risks of school transmission.   https://t.co/bLUMQStzeZ

The positive impact of all of these individual actions and gov policies and actions will be substantial.  Without these collective actions and goals, cases will rise, confidence will fall, and the overall struggle with COVID will worsen.20/x

Governors will need to monitor carefully as they move to reopen. If COVID hospitalizations + ICU bed use go down, that's good news. If they go up substantially, that's bad, and difficult decisions will need to be made about what distancing interventions may need to re-start.19/x

It has become more clear every week how testing could help institutions move more confidently toward reopening, recovery. Don’t just need testing for people w/ symptoms of COVID, we need it for businesses, universities, other orgs that want to use it to screen people.13/x

In terms of how this relates to other major US causes of death, in the last couple of months, there have been many days when COVID19 was the leading cause of death that day in the country.  https://t.co/tuGSkZaUxt 5/x

And though it was claimed by some at the start of this pandemic, #COVID19 is not the flu (influenza).  Flu last year killed about 34,000 people in the US over the 2018-2019 flu season.  COVID19 has already killed three times that in about 11 wks.3/x

Many of these 100,000 were healthy or doing fine before they got COVID19. They had families and friends, who were largely not allowed to be with their loved ones when they died. A really tragic part of this epidemic.2/x

The US has reached a terrible milestone of 100,000 lives lost to COVID19.  It’s important to stop to think about how this disease has hurt the country, and to focus on what needs to happen to lessen the impact and spread of this epidemic in the time ahead.1/x

Median age of pts was 73 years (interquartile range 58-82, range 0-104). 310 pts (1.5%) were < 18 y/o, and 194 (1.0%) were < 5 years old. More men (59.9%) than women (40.1%,) were admitted to hospital with covid-19. 5/x
The pts included in the study were approx 34% of the 59,215 covid-19 admissions in these countries. Median time from onset of COVID symptoms in community to presentation at hospital was 4 days 4/x

Sorry to see that some of our top health officials have been exposed to COVID and have to be quarantined.  I very much hope they stay well.  We need the advice and direction of top health and science officials to steer the COVID response  https://t.co/rOxxSDLsxC

Another way to look at this -- if you add up US 65 y/o and older population together with those w/ underlying conditions that put them at risk for COVID, you get >90M adults  https://t.co/tN4lAt5X64 13/x

There have been 143,000 cases of COVID in nursing home pts and staff, w/ 25,600 deaths. It’s terribly high proportion of all those who have lost their lives to COVID.  We need continued and stronger focus on protecting pts and staff in nursing homes https://t.co/OD024mqAxz 10/x

From same NPR story -- so far only 1 state has met anticipated contact tracing need, with a small number of others on track to get to their benchmark. Some states continue to have many hundreds of new COVID cases a day which will make contact tracing hugely complex operation 8/x

Still many places need more testing for those w/ possible COVID symptoms. Also many businesses, universities, orgs want access to diagnostic testing for COVID as part of their reopening plans. For most part, there is not enough testing to make that happen yet. 6/x

Also for perspective, ~ 78,000 people have died in the US from COVID, the majority over the past 5 wks.  In 2018-2019 in the US, ~ 34,200 people died of influenza over the course of the flu year.2/x  https://t.co/W8BCVrkrOF

Comments on recent #COVID19 US developments, some positive, some not:  US still in plateau w/ daily 25-30,000 cases and average of ~2000 daily deaths for ~5 wks.  For perspective, the average number of US deaths on a given day is ~ 7,700.  https://t.co/ZC5zMjpddF 1/x

In any event, systematic COVID testing of resp specimens from around country should be getting done-@CDCgov, state health depts, research institutions to look for evidence COVID was in US earlier, and where.  If it was here earlier than we've recognized, very important to know

Florida reported to have had number of cases of COVID19 as early as end of Dec, beginning of Jan https://t.co/NNg5LDzgqU  If true would be earlier than the first recognized case in US who had first symptoms on Jan 16th.

Highly respected pub health leader Peter Piot recovering from serious #COVID19 infxn.  Makes the point that we shouldn't just focus on mortality rates but also know that substantial numbers of survivors from this illness will likely have long term sequelae https://t.co/IPqf7poiE1
